text: Hi, welcome to another video tutorial from Polymath Learning Center. Today we'll be going through a question that requires the use of two concepts to solve the question will involve the equating numerator concept and the grouping all numbers value concept. The question is, Andy had some $1 coins and Ben had some 50 cent coins. After Andy used one third of his coins and Ben used four over seven of his coins, they had the same number of coins left. Given that Andy and Ben had a total of $352 at first, how many coins did Andy have at first? As usual in Polymath Learning Center will teach you how to identify a concept before going through the solution. An increasing humorative question involves a proportion of an object being equal to another proportion of another object in the question. After Nd and Ben has spent certain fractions of the coins, the remaining fractions of the coins are the same. In a grouping question, you are given the proportion between the number of two or more items. However, the items have different values each. Thus, the proportion between the total value of the items will be different from the proportion between the number of items in the question. We will find out the proportion between the number of coins Andy and Ben had. However, Andy had $1 coin which is different in value to the 50 cent coins the bank had. Thus, we have to group the coins with different values together to solve the question. Now we should start solving question. Since Andy used one third of his coins, we can find the fraction of his remaining coins by subtracting one third from whole. This will give us two thirds of his coins remaining. Similarly, by subtracting four over seven from one whole, we can find a fraction of the coin span half remaining, which is three over seven. Since the question tells us that Nd and band had the same number of coins remaining, the remaining portions of Nd and banned coins are equal. Let's use the model to understand this concept better. Since two out of three units of ND's coins are equal to three out of seven of Ben's coins, we draw two units of Nd aligning with three units of band. We then add back the missing units to reflect the total number of units they have, adding the previously used one unit for Nd and four units for Ben. Since the two units from Nd is equal to the three units from Ben, we want to cut them into same sized units. The lowest common multiple of three and two is six. Thus, we cut each of these units into three and we cut each advanced units into two. We not only cut the aligned portions into the new units also cut the new sink units we have at the back as well so that we end up with the same units for both Nd and this cutting of the model is the same as making the numerator the same for the equation on the left. However, in order to change the two fractions numerators without changing the proportion of the fractions, we have to multiply the denominators of the fractions by the same number as well. Therefore, we multiply both the numerator and denominator for Andy's fraction by three and multiply band's fraction by two. After multiplying we can see that the original number of units for Nd and Ben are nine units and 14 units respectively. We can now express Nd coins and Banks coins in the ratio lines to 14 even though we have the ratio of the number of coins. You must remember that the values of the coins are different and these coins are worth $1 each while Banks coins are only worth $0.50 each. We solve this problem by grouping nine of one dollars coins. With 14 advanced 50 cent coins we will get a value of $16 for each group that we group this way since the value of one group is $16 and then had a total of $352 at first we divide $352 by $16 to find out that there are 22 groups of these coins in total. Since each group has nine of these coins we multiply 22 groups by nine coins to get answered. 198 there you have it please like and subscribe to this channel if you enjoyed this one and check out all other videos I will see you in the next video. Bye.

Since two out of three units of ND's coins are equal to three out of seven of Ben's coins, we draw two units of Nd aligning with three units of band.

We then add back the missing units to reflect the total number of units they have, adding the previously used one unit for Nd and four units for Ben. We not only cut the aligned portions into the new units also cut the new sink units we have at the back as well so that we end up with the same units for both Nd and this cutting of the model is the same as making the numerator the same for the equation on the left. 198 there you have it please like and subscribe to this channel if you enjoyed this one and check out all other videos I will see you in the next video. Bye.
